newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Northeast spot power steady amid cool weather - SEP 24.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Northeast spot power steady amid cool weather - SEP 24.

text.p: Spot electricity prices in the northeastern U.S. ended Tuesday steady against Monday's quotes amid cool weather settling into the region, market sources said.
Along Northeast's U.S./Canadian border, temperatures were forecast to peak in the 50's Fahrenheit Wednesday. The rest of the region were predicted to experience weather in the 60 to 70 degree range.
Lack of weather-related demand for cooling and heating was offset by tight generation capacity in the Northeast linked to the outages of a couple of nuclear power plants in the region.
New York Power Authority's 800 Fitzpatrick station in Scriba, N.Y., began producing power today, and would not resume full output at least until Wednesday.
Boston Edison Co pushed back the restart of its 670 MW Pilgrim plant in Plymouth, Mass., to Saturday from Wednesday because additional inspection time was needed.

In the New York Power Pool (NYPP), non-firm electricity for peak load hours on Wednesday was assessed near $19.00 a megawatt hour (MWh) in the western part of the state, down from Monday's quote of $20.00.
Next-day power prices in eastern NYPP, was valued at $22.00, flat from Monday.

In the New England Power Pool (NEPOOL), peak, non-firm electricity prices for Wednesday was pegged at $28.00-$30.00 at the Northeast Utilities' territory border, a wider range than Monday's $29.25-$29.75.
